documents.title: that 's it for today !
text: guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 2:03pm well , my time here in the bustling guardian hq is done .
as you 'd expect , all the men have beards , and the women have gone for a natural look .
it 's been very nice talking to you , and your questions have only served to confirm my opinion : that one in five of the general public is mad .
i do hope you enjoy reading the bolds , and remember : i am now a respectable children 's author .
goodbye .
thanks very much to everyone who posted questions , and to julian for his answers .
cheers !

documents.title: `` i owe it all to the book 'stop thinking , start living ' , seriously ''
text: ian4201 asks : i recall you have in the past recommended the book stop thinking , start living ( which i then bought , and found it very good ) i wondered , now , what is your basic philosophy of life , you seem very settled and content .
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 2:01pm i owe it all to that book , seriously .
the basic trick , not that it 's new , is to live life in the moment .
you know the sort of thing .
i think maybe buddha thought of it first , it 's fair to say .
frothwrath asks : do you like carrots that much ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 2:00pm yes ?
and your point is ?
glyn1929 asks : amazing .
i also have a gardener called glyn .
he 's always walking around without his top on .
i tell him to cover up as he 's frightening the neighbours .
what would you do ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:59pm there 's no job too big or too small for my glynn .
pumpkined asks : hello julian a young cad once told me i was a hyena in a former life .
what might you have been ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:58pm a respectable children 's author .
pumpkined asks : another question , sorry being greedy .
i totally love your songs , especially dropped me like a brick .
if you could have one of your songs played on the wireless and be an international hit , what would it be and why ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:57pm how sweet !
i can think of two of my own songs that i 'd like to hear on the wireless , as you so quaintly put it , both quite recent : probably you 're gay , or cool to be queer .
not that i 'm a homosexual or anything .
icklewickle says : and how did the rest of the gay community react to your success ?

do n't you get tired of people assuming that anyone of any particular orientation , race , creed , faith , etc , etc , etc thinks exactly the same way , in the same manner that starlings in their murmur swoop , or schools of fish angle and turn ?
having said that , i 've been an admirer of yours for many years , since the ftwd and joan collins fanclub days .
thanks for you being you .
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:55pm whatever you 're on , i 'd like some .
ejmd asks : fanny the wonderdog : whatever happened ?
and while we 're at it , norman lamont : have you ever met to discuss things and , if so , did you manage to make a good fist of it ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:54pm fanny the wonder dog died two days after my 40th birthday , in 1999 .
she was 19 , a good innings as they say .
i love the fact that she is still remembered today and if i talk about her on stage she gets a posthumous round of applause , which is rather touching .
ellie kane asks : why have n't you ever done a sitcom ?
british sit coms are so dire these days , you could save the whole medium !
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:52pm i refer you to my 1991 contribution to the sitcom genre , terry and julian .
available on youtube .
glyn1929 asks : how much gardening do you do ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:50pm none to be honest .
i have a cheerful gardener called andrew , and an oddjob man with tattoos called glynn .
i waft around in a kimono pointing at things and they do the rest .
it 's my way of giving something back to the community .
finishhimoffsoo asks : in that with the book you look like mid-career barry manilow .
have you ever met him ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:49pm no i 've never met barry manilow .
as for the comparisons you notice , i am contacting my lawyers .

documents.title: on being neighbours with paul o'grady
text: mattyjj asks : when you converse over the fence with mr o'grady , do you ever find yourself unconsciously mimicking his dulcet birkenhead tones ?
or is really all an act and he talks like brian sewell in real life ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:48pm it 's not an act .
he 's as common as muck .
we do n't speak over the fence very often to be honest , unless i 'm pleading him to turn the music down on a friday night .
you have to grab your window of opportunity though because by 10.30pm he 'll have had so much cider he 'll be on his hands and knees on the village green .
leglesszebra asks : looking forward to reading the book , sounds fab .
what was your favourite book as a child ?
did you like paddington ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:47pm i was more of a rupert the bear kind of gal .
amazing things would happen to rupert : giant birds would swoop down and fly him off to china when he 'd only gone out for a stroll with bill badger .
it was surreal .
aesthetically as well , he was a far more handsome bear than paddington .
frankbarclay asks : why did you turn down the job as main presenter of the new top gear ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:45pm i was busy washing my hair .
sabrinacoo94 asks : hi julian , a few questions about your new book !
was there a children 's author that inspired you to write a children 's book ?
and do you have any plans to write a sequel ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:44pm before i started writing the bolds i re-read just william by richmal crompton , just to get me in the mood .
the sequel , the bolds to the rescue , is already written and will come out next february .
the third bolds book ( is there no end to this nonsense ? )
has been conceived and i am currently gestating .

documents.title: `` i 'm rather keen on lord sewel i think he 's a scream . and i 'm thinking of inviting him for a night out in soho ''
text: apatheticzealot asks : do you agree with the honours system ?
and if you were to be called to the purple , would you prefer to be known as sir julian clary or dame julian clary ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:42pm you ca n't really justify the honours system , but it 's camp is n't it ?
therefore i 'm all for it .
i 'm looking forward to kneeling down in front of prince charles , to receive whatever he 'd like to give me .
an mbe maybe ( mincer of the british empire ) .
i 'm rather keen on lord sewel - i think he 's a scream .
and i 'm thinking of inviting him for a night out in soho .
i know clubs where his particular look would go down very well .
mattyjj asks : am i really the only person in the uk who likes vicious ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:37pm no , my friend hector quite likes it .

c8th3r1n3 asks : oh can i ask another one what do you think about the shooting of that poor lyon cecil in zimbabwe , and the shooter said i did n't realise i had done anything wrong wtf while it was bad to shoot cecil , is n't it hideous that hunting endangered species is commercialised in this way or is it a way that these species can be bread and perhaps survive extinction all be it for the purposes of bloody nasty people 's so-called sport ?
i do n't know which way is best to protect endangered species .
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:37pm i ca n't understand anyone wanting to kill an animal , beautiful or otherwise .
why not just `` shoot it '' with a camera ?
while filming nature nuts , i sat for five hours on a riverbank waiting for a water vole to make an appearance and was suitably thrilled when it did .
i rather like the fact that the dentist from minnesota is now being hunted himself on social media .
i 'm not sure where this is all leading though .
he may have to invest in plastic surgery and start a new life somewhere like the isle of wight .
maybe he could take his bow and arrow with him and sort out some seagulls .
or is that wrong of me ?
c8th3r1n3 asks : you 're great obviously , but do you really like panto ?
it 's just that you 're so good and i wonder if you do love it or do you prefer stand-up presenting or writing ?

guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:32pm i like panto because it 's one time of the year that i am part of a huge production with dancing girls and boys , special effects , and a live band .
touring on my own is a far more solitary affair .
although i love it .
panto also takes care of december and january - those dreary months when if i was n't doing 12 shows a week , i might have to attend hideous christmas parties or the january sales .
also , let 's face it , it pays rather well .
i need the cash .
as dolly parton put it , `` it costs a lot of money to look this cheap . ''
amsterdamned asks : you obviously have quite a complex tv persona have we ever seen the real julian ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:27pm you know me as a `` camp comic and renowned homosexual '' , and the truth is , there is n't much more to tell .
according to my partner , i 'm shallow and self-absorbed .
he said a few other things too , but i 'm afraid i 'd glazed over by then .
middleyouth asks : you 're roughly the same age as me .
how do you now look 20 years younger ?
and would you ever wear the jcfc costumes these days ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:24pm the secret of my youthful appearance i stole from mae west , who had an enema every day at 1pm .
it is now 1.22pm and i am in a glass booth at the guardian 's offices there 's a small puddle underneath my chair .
the joan collins fan club costumes were mostly made of latex .
i opened the wardrobe in which i keep them a few years ago , to see if they still fitted my taut frame , and unfortunately they had turned to gloop .
that 's the trouble with rubber : it does n't last .
rhyyyyy asks : how did simon mayo manage to keep talking after he asked you if the beaver was your favourite and you replied it 's all down to personal taste ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:20pm simon mayo is a very professional broadcaster .
he did n't bat an eyelid when the conversation turned to beavers , and there was no innuendo intended on my part .
we were discussing my new tv show britain 's nature nuts which starts on sunday , itv1 at 7pm .
but i am a respectable children 's author and unfortunately you 're seeing lurid references where there simply are n't any .
bernardcrofton asks : as a lad i was always warned off going near noel 's house .
so of course i used to ride over , hide my bike , and lie under the hedge to try and see what was going on that i should stay away from .
i never saw anything other than people getting into a car and driving away .
did i miss something ?
and is it more interesting there now ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:18pm are you referring to noel coward 's house , or noel edmonds ' ?
i really do n't like to think of you lying under a hedge - what on earth were you expecting to see ?
how do i know what you missed ?
i was n't there .
noel coward was of course famous for the fabulous parties he had in what is now my house ( he was also famous for writing plays and songs , obviously ) .
the cream of british showbiz and royalty would be there .
i throw the odd soiree , but you 'll be lucky to get a glimpse of christopher biggins at one of my do 's .
unfortunately i live next door to paul o'grady .
it 's like living next door to the dingles .
not what i 'd hoped for .

documents.title: `` the bolds is about tolerance and integration . as is usual with these things , i only spotted the moral of the story once i 'd finished it ''
text: celticchick asks : hi julian would you say your new book is allegorical ?
maybe for adults as well ?
sounds interesting !
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:14pm i 'm not sure if the bolds is an allegory in the same sense as animal farm is of the russian revolution .
i would n't be that highbrow and nor do you want me to be .
but it has a message !
it 's about tolerance and integration .
as is usual with these things , i only spotted the moral of the story once i 'd finished it .
i did n't set out with that intention , but it appeared as if by magic .
as a child i came to the conclusion that animals were just as intelligent as human beings , who wrongly assume themselves to be superior .
in the bolds , animals have `` transitioned '' to live amongst us all in suburbia , and this is the story of how they hide their secret , conceal their tails , and their natural instincts .
much hilarity ensues , etc .
allison carey asks : was writing the bolds easier than writing your adult novels ?
guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:07pm writing the bolds was a liberating experience to free myself from the filth and innuendo the adult public might expect of me .
it was easy and joyful to write , i simply located my inner child ( not difficult in my case ) and away i went .
the story arrived in my mind fully formed , and there was no artistic anguish or soul-searching .
in fact , the story of the bolds ( a family of hyenas living in suburbia ) is one i invented for myself as a child growing up in teddington .
i simply had to recall it and write it down .
then there 's the excitement of david roberts ' illustrations which give the whole thing another dimension .
i 'm rather surprised to find myself writing children 's literature .
whatever next ?
designing my own maternity wear range ?
i would n't put it past me .

documents.title: 'i recently saved joan collins 's life '
text: craig barnes asks : how did you come to finally meet joan collins , and what do you find most appealing about her now you are friends ?

guardian contributor julianclary1 30 july 2015 1:03pm apart from a few frosty encounters on daytime tv chatshows , i did n't meet joan properly until we both starred in jack and the beanstalk together , in 2010 .
i was giving my spirit of the bells , and joan ( jane to you ) was queen rat .
joan was wary of me because i used to call myself the joan collins fanclub back in the day .
but we were in adjoining dressing rooms at the birmingham hippodrome , and she soon thawed out .
we play poker together these days , and i recently saved her life following an unfortunate incident in her luxurious swimming pool in st tropez .
i was on a sunlounger reading an erotic gay novel ; joan , in full drag , was floating in the deep end on some giant throne which suddenly turned over , trapping her underneath .
she was wearing a chiffon scarf at the time ( as you do ) and what with that and her giant sunhat she was almost a goner .
without a thought for my own safety i flung myself , fully clothed , into the water and saved joan collins ' life .
for which she and the entire nation should be eternally grateful .
joan is a wonderful , energetic woman , and looks nothing like her 142 years .

text: here he is at guardian towers with , yes , his book : beaumont-thomas

documents.title: post your questions for julian clary
text: julian clary has long made a career out outrageous double entrendres , or indeed single ones whether it 's calling a tour position vacant : apply within , making references to sucking a fisherman 's friend , or scandalising the comedy awards with a certain reference to norman lamont .
but amid the bawdy humour and frequent reality tv appearances , there have been moments of real poignancy , such as his turn as the emcee in rufus norris 's celebrated production of cabaret .
he 's now written his first children 's book , the bolds , which is published this month .

it 's the tale of a group of hyenas who , having learned english from overhearing safari-goers , up sticks for teddington in middlesex to have a go at middle-class life it 's full of clary 's arch wit .
he 's joining to discuss it and anything else in his career in a live webchat , at 1pm bst on thursday 30 july post your questions in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .
